column1: Cedar Hill is a city in Dallas and Ellis counties in the U.S. state of Texas. It is located approximately 16 miles (26 km) southwest of downtown Dallas and is situated along the eastern shore of Joe Pool Lake and Cedar Hill State Park. The population was 45
column2: 028 at the 2010 census.Cedar Hill is a suburb of Dallas and is part of the Best Southwest area
column3: which includes the nearby cities of DeSoto
column4: Duncanville

column2: Cedar Hill lay along a branch of the Chisholm Trail and served as the temporary county seat of Dallas County. In 1856
column3: a tornado swept through the town killing nine people and destroying most of its buildings. The seat of the county was moved to Dallas not long after.

column1: Cedar Hill was founded around 1846 by a small group of settlers from the Peters Colony.  They came from Kentucky
column2: Alabama
column3: and surrounding areas to arrive in the Dallas area of North Texas.  197 families and 184 single men settled in what is now Cedar Hill
column4: making it the largest settlement in the area at the time.Cedar Hill has five homes listed on the National Park Service's National Register of Historic Places
column5: 4 historical structures on the Texas Historical Commission's list of Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks
column6: and 2 graveyards designated as "Historical Texas Cemeteries" by the Texas Historical Commission
column7: one of which is believed to be the oldest integrated cemetery in Dallas County.

column3: Cedar Hill was struck by a tornado that claimed at least nine lives
column4: damaged property
column6: and reportedly left only two structures standing.  Among the survivors was teacher and pastor
column7: Robert Crawford.  Crawford donated four acres of his land to church trustees to be designated as a free and indiscriminate public graveyard.  Nine victims of the tornado were buried on Crawford's land.The graveyard lay lost for about 100 years. It was rediscovered and certified by the Texas Historical Commission in 2006
column8: and was named the Crawford Tornado Graveyard.  The graveyard was reconsecrated in a blessing ceremony on October 7
column9: 2011.  The Texas Historical Commission marker was officially placed on the site on April 29

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 35.9 square miles (93.0 km2)
column3: of which 35.8 square miles (92.8 km2) is land and 0.08 square miles (0.2 km2)
column5: is water.It is sometimes referred to as the "hill country of Dallas" (in comparison to the "hill country" surrounding Austin and San Antonio). The city is full of native eastern red cedar evergreen trees and stands at an elevation of about 800 feet (240 m) above sea level—the highest point in a straight line from the Red River at the Texas-Oklahoma border to the Gulf Coast.

column1: Because of its elevation many local radio and TV stations have their antennas located there. Pulse-Doppler weather radar equipment for tracking tornadoes are also attached to these steel antennas that reach several thousand feet into the air and whose blinking lights appear like Christmas trees at night.
The "Austin chalk" limestone uplift on which most of Cedar Hill is spread is covered with "gumbo"-cleche-clay topsoil from a few inches to many feet. The western edge of the city
column2: primarily the Lake Ridge neighborhood
column3: falls below the limestone uplift on the Eagle Ford shale strata surrounding Joe Pool Lake.

column1: Most of the city is served by the Cedar Hill Independent School District. Some of it is served by Duncanville Independent School District and the Midlothian Independent School District.

The Cedar Hill ISD portion is served by Cedar Hill High School and Cedar Hill Collegiate High School.  The Duncanville ISD portion is served by Duncanville High School.  The Midlothian ISD portion is served by Midlothian High School.

column1: Cedar Hill has set aside 20% of its land for parks and green space.  3
column2: 000 acres of nature reserves and preserves are located in Cedar Hill including Dogwood Canyon and Cedar Hill State Park.

column1: Dogwood Canyon was formed by the convergence of two ecosystems: the Blackland Prairie
column2: which covers the majority of Dallas County
column3: and the white rock of the Austin Chalk deposits.Wildlife living in the canyon include birds such as the painted bunting
column4: black-capped vireo
column6: the latter two of which are endangered.  Wildlife species include bobcats

column1: The canyon is named for the flowering Dogwoods found throughout the escarpment.  Other plant life found in Dogwood Canyon include the White trout-lily as well as three species of Hexalectris orchids
column2: which are among only a few hundred in the country.

column1: Cedar Hill State Park opened in 1991
column2: and is located on the northeast corner of Joe Pool Lake.  The park consists of 1
column3: 826 acres of land and miles of shoreline.  The area is a transition zone between the rolling tallgrass prairie with its black clay soil and the rugged limestone escarpment.The park considers the native tallgrass prairie remnants to be its most important natural feature.  In the early 1800s a vast tallgrass prairie stretched from Texas to Canada.  Today
column4: less than one percent survives.  These endangered remnants include Indian grass
column8: and switchgrass.  The park has reintroduced Eastern gamma grass and meadow pinks in selected areas.In the wooded hills of the park
column14: and raccoons. Lake fishing is good for largemouth bass
column17: and catfish.The Cedar Hill State Park has approximately 200 species of birds and is home to many other Neotropical migrants.  The most sought after bird at the park is the painted bunting

column1: Cedar Hill rests on the edge of Joe Pool Lake.  The lake was impounded in 1986
column2: has a surface area of 6
column3: 469 acres and a maximum depth of 75 feet.  Joe Pool Lake can be accessed through the Cedar Hill State Park or any other of the three parks located along its borders.

column2: Cedar Hill became home to what was then known as Hill Tower.  At 880 feet above sea level
column3: Cedar Hill's elevation made it a desirable location for installation of the broadcast antennas.  Hill Tower was the first single tower owned and operated by two television stations at the same time.During this time
column4: then CBS affiliate
column7: were the leading television stations of Dallas. Both stations were in competition for the same location
column8: thus the idea of Hill Tower was born.   The tower would reach over 1
column9: 500 feet into the sky and be topped with an 80-foot triangular platform consisting of two antennas
column10: one for each station.  Dubbed 'the candelabra'
column11: both antennas were of equal height and equal centers of radiation.Since the construction of Hill Tower
column12: many other local television and radio stations have located here
column14: mobile communications technology service providers.  Today
column15: Cedar Hill has the highest concentration of radio and television communication antennas in the county with 14 towers.Visible from 20 miles away on a clear night
column16: the towers have become a landmark for travelers.  They also serve as a navigational landmark for aircraft pilots who use the towers as a guide.

column1: Farmers such as John Wesley Penn utilized the natural resources of the land to build farms and provided shelter and sustenance for their families.  The Penn family lived and grazed livestock on the native prairie grasses for over a hundred years.  During that time
column2: most of the tallgrass prairie in Dallas County vanished – plowed under and replaced with crops of wheat or cotton. Perhaps because of the rocky surface and hilly terrain of the Cedar Hill area
column3: the prairie remnants at Penn Farm survived and are maintained today.Penn Farm Agricultural History Center was created from the remnants of Penn Farm
column4: which date back to the 1850s.  The center is located within Cedar Hill State Park.  It was designed to educate people about early life in Cedar Hill and to demonstrate how human invention rendered the greatest impact on the tallgrass prairie once prominent in this area.  Many of the original structures still remain standing
column5: showing the evolution of machinery constructed and adapted by the Penn family as needs changed and modern conveniences were added.

column1: Dogwood Canyon Audubon Center was built as a partnership between Cedar Hill and the National Audubon Society.  On April 23
column3: John Flicker
column4: former president of the National Audubon Society
column5: led the groundbreaking ceremonies for the Dogwood Canyon Audubon Center.  The Center officially opened in 2011.The visitor center has been awarded Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) Gold Certification
column6: established by the U.S. Green Building Council and verified by the Green Building Certification Institute (GBCI)
column10: and material use as well as incorporating a variety of other sustainable strategies.In 2015
column11: Dogwood Canyon Audubon Center partnered with the Cedar Hill Independent School District on a study linking outdoor science education to academic performance.  The study involved 500 5th grade students from Cedar Hill ISD.  The students participated weekly in the Audubon Center's customized Eco Investigations lessons.  Those who participated scored 20% higher on related STAAR questions then nonparticipants.  This study is the first of its kind in Texas.

column1: Cedar Hill currently has over 45 miles of multi-purpose
column2: integrated trails and bikeways.  Most recent additions include Pleasant Run Trail
column3: Lake Ridge Hike and Bike Trail
column4: and Red Oak Creek Trail.DORBA Trail is the longest trail located in Cedar Hill State Park and is a shared use hike and bike trail.  The trail was created through the efforts of the Dallas Off-Road Bicycle Association
column6: and the Cedar Hill State Park management.  It is considered one of the top mountain biking trails in the state.An ADA accessible trail can be found at the Dogwood Canyon Audubon Center.

column1: The climate in this area is characterized by hot
column2: humid summers and generally mild to cool winters.  According to the Köppen Climate Classification system
column3: Cedar Hill has a humid subtropical climate
column4: abbreviated "Cfa" on climate maps. This type of weather is typical throughout the densely populated parts of the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex.
